content.description:
CONSUMER DURABLES IN COMMUNIST BULGARIA PER 100 HOUSEHOLDS: 1965 AND 1983
 19651983Radios5992Televisions887Electric washing machines2381Refrigerators588Private cars234Source: Adapted from Kristen Ghodsee, “Red Nostalgia? Communism, Women’s Emancipation, and Economic Transformation in Bulgaria,” European Journal of Feminist History, 2004. http://scholar.harvard.edu/files/kristenghodsee/files/lhomme-1-2004-ghodsee.pdf
content.question: Which of the following most accurately compares the changes shown in Bulgaria with changes in Western Europe during the same period?

choices.label: Growth in the availability of consumer goods in Western Europe was significantly behind that of Bulgaria.
Growth in the availability of consumer goods in Western Europe was similar to that of Bulgaria, but it started from a higher level.
Growth in the availability of consumer goods in Western Europe was stagnant during this period compared to that of Bulgaria.
Consumer goods became less available in Western Europe, compared to Bulgaria, as people in Western Europe began to question the materialistic values of consumer culture.

content.answer: Growth in the availability of consumer goods in Western Europe was similar to that of Bulgaria, but it started from a higher level.

topic.text: 9.14: 20th- and 21st-Century Culture, Arts, and Demographic Trends

skill.text: Skill 5.A: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.
